fields.exhibition_history:
Venetian Visions (Victoria and Albert Museum, Galleries 88a and 90 07/10/11-01/04/12)
Canaletto e Bellotto: L'arte della veduta (Palazzo Bricherasio, Turin 14/03/2008-15/06/2008)
fields.bibliography: Ward Jackson, Peter. Italian Drawings (London: Her Majesty's Stationary Office, 1979), vol. II, pp. 116-7, cat.927. The following is the full text of the catalogue entry: 'BELOTTO, BERNARDO called Canaletto (1720-80) 927 Architectural caprice Signed 'Bernardo Belotto de Canaletto Inv. et Fec.1764' Pen and ink and wash 17¼ x 24¼ (438 x 616) E.30-1939 PROVENANCE Given by Miss A. Simonson in memory of her brother George Simonson LITERATURE See no. 926 There are reminiscences here of the campanile of St Mark's, Venice, and of the Colleoni monument, while the seated figures round the base of the equestrian monument are borrowed from Tacca's monument to Ferdinand I at Leghorn. Another version of the drawing is in the National Museum, Warsaw (see H. A. Fritzsche, Bernardo Belotto, Burg bei Magdeburg, 1936, p. 136, no. Vz.115, and pl. 31). It is unfinished, with no shading and the ruled perspective lines still visible.' Peter Ward Jackson, 1979 Canaletto e Bellotto: L'arte della veduta / a cura di Bozena Anna Kowalczyk Milano: Silvana Editoriale, 2008. 263p : ill (chiefly col). Exhibition catalogue
fields.credit: Given by Miss A. Simonson in memory of her brother George Simonson
fields.history_note: Given by Miss A. Simonson in memory of her brother George Simonson. Historical significance: Bellotto was the son of Lorenzo Bellotto and Fiorenza Domenica Canale, sister of the famous view painter Antonio Canaletto (DATES). His artistic talent seems to have been spotted early on with his uncle beginning to train him when Bellotto was in his early teens. He was enrolled in the Venetian painter's guild in 1738 at the young age of sixteen. He produced many of the compositions that had been developed by Canaletto, possibly following this successful example or to help fulfil the numerous commissions received by his uncle. Approximately 55 Venetian views are known by Bellotto and many of his capricci date to his time in Venice. This early period shows the artist quickly developing his artistic skills. In the 1740s he travelled throughout Italy visiting cities including Milan, Rome and Turin. All these journeys resulted in groups of view paintings. His Venetian period came to an end with his departure for Dresden in the spring of 1747. He would never return to Venice. This marked the beginning of a period of three decades where he would enjoy patronage in the Northern European courts, including Munich and Vienna as well as Dresden. He eventually settled in Warsaw, where he continued to work until his death. The drawing is signed 'Bernardo Belotto de Canaletto Inv. Et Fec. 1764' in the lower left corner. The composition combines various recognisable architectural motifs. In the left building behind which consists of the arches of the prisons on the ground floor and an arcade reminiscent of the Ducal Palace above can be seen beyond an arch from the Marciana library, Venice. The base of the Equestrian monument in the right mid ground recalls that of the Colleoni sistuated in the Piazza di San Giovanni e Paolo, Venice. However the statue itself is closer to that of Augusto II in the Neustadt, Dresden. The view opens out to show a distant town on the other side of the lagoon. Here a tower that recalls that of the Campanile in Saint Mark's Square, Venice, contrasts with the taller round tower on the right which has a northern European feel. There is an earlier drawing for this work in the National Museum, Warsaw. The Warsaw drawing is unfinished, with no shading and ruled lines of perspective still available. The drawing was acquired with another similar Architectural Caprice by Bellotto (inventory number E.31-1939). Both these works are highly finished and present architectural motifs in an almost theatrical way. Unlike most capricci of the eighteenth century, these drawings do not include figures, giving the main focus of each work to the architectural detail and spaces.
